thread.title: North East March for Europe set to take place in Newcastle
thread.title_full: North East March for Europe set to take place in Newcastle

author: Mike Kelly
title: North East March for Europe set to take place in Newcastle
text:
News North East March for Europe set to take place in Newcastle A large crowd is predicted at the Newcastle march and speakers include work renowned philosopher Prof AC Grayling and Baroness Quin Share EU and Union flags (Photo: PA) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A pro-Europe march is to take place in Newcastle on Saturday which organisers hope will be the biggest event of its kind in the region. 
Supporters from across the country and the political divide are expected to gather for the start at the Newcastle City Pool at 12pm. 
They will then march to the Monument in Grey Street and listen to speeches from a number of high profile speakers like world renowned philosopher and author Professor AC Grayling and former North East Labour MEP and Minister for Europe Joyce Quin. 
The North East for Europe group which has organised it said they wished to show solidarity with fellow EU citizens living in the North East who are concerned about their right to live and work here. 
The march follows the defeat of the government’s Brexit bill the House of Lords last week which said ministers should guarantee EU nationals’ right to stay in the UK after Brexit. Grey's Monument on Grey Street, Newcastle 
The vote, by 358 to 256, is the first Parliamentary defeat for the government’s Brexit bill. 
However, MPs will be able to remove their changes when the bill returns to the House of Commons. 
And a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said she remained “committed” to meeting the deadline to trigger Article 50 by the end of March. 
He said: “Our message to MPs is that we expect this bill to go through unamended. 
“MPs voted it through unamended and we expect that to be the case.” 
Ms Quin - now Baroness Quin - was in the Lords for the vote. 
She said: “I voted for the amendment. The Lords is a revising chamber and doesn’t block legislation and the reality is the government will get its legislation through. Baroness Joyce Quin, former prisons and probation minister and former Labour MP for Gateshead East and Washington West (Photo: Sunday Mercury) 
“What I’m therefore concerned about is very much the prosperity of our country and the prosperity of the North East. 
“Whichever way people voted it wasn’t to get a worse deal than the one we have at present.” 
Ms Quin said she wasn’t taking to protest about Brexit and overturn it. 
“The vote is a fact and the government will begin the process.” 
However she commented that what she wanted was to maintain strong links with Europe and keep in place EU legislation like on environmental issues, which has give the UK cleaner beaches and cleaner drinking water. 
She said: “The referendum result was quite close. A lot of people voted to keep many of our links.” Read More 
However, her views appear to be at odds with her fellow speaker at the Newcastle event Prof Grayling, judging by comments he made about Brexit this week. 
Prof Grayling said: “The growing number of people who have grave reservations about Brexit should be heard. 
“If the choice is between a poor Brexit deal and no deal, the national interest requires decision-makers to rethink a deeply damaging course of action. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
